quiz.title: Unit 7: Imperfect Competition (Quiz 9)
quiz.subtitle: AP Microeconomics — Monopoly Profit Maximization & Regulation
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Monopoly Pricing, Profit Maximization, Regulation, Socially Optimal Pricing, Fair-Return Pricing, Deadweight Loss, Barriers to Entry, Oligopoly Kinked Demand, Monopolistic Competition, Excess Capacity, Total Revenue, Socially Optimal Price, Game Theory, Oligopoly Barriers

questions.question: Refer to the graph shown. What is the profit-maximizing price and quantity for this monopolist?
questions.explanation: A monopolist maximizes profit where MR = MC (intersection at Q1). To find price, go up from Q1 to the demand curve, then left to the price axis: P5.

questions.question: If the government were to regulate the monopoly pictured in the graph shown so that they must produce at the 'socially optimal' amount, what would be the price and quantity?
questions.explanation: The socially optimal (allocatively efficient) output occurs where P = MC (demand curve intersects MC curve). On this graph, that intersection is at quantity Q2 and price P4.

questions.question: If the government were to regulate the monopoly pictured in the graph shown so that they must produce at the fair return or break-even point, what would be the price & quantity?
questions.explanation: The fair-return (zero economic profit) point occurs where P = ATC. On the graph, the demand curve intersects the ATC curve at price P3 and quantity Q3.

questions.question: If the government wants to ensure no deadweight loss for a monopoly, it will set the price that equals:
questions.explanation: Deadweight loss is eliminated when price equals marginal cost (P = MC), which is the socially efficient outcome where the value of the last unit equals the cost of producing it.

questions.question: Relative to perfect competition, a monopoly will produce a ___ amount and charge a ____ price.
questions.explanation: A monopoly restricts output below the competitive level to raise price above marginal cost, resulting in lower quantity and higher price compared to perfect competition.

questions.question: A barrier to entry is
options: A law established by the government to protect new industries.
A commitment on the part of big business to allow smaller companies to compete.
An obstacle that prevents additional workers from entering an industry, such as a union.
Any obstacle that makes it difficult for new firms to enter a market.
questions.explanation: A barrier to entry is defined as any obstacle that makes it difficult for new firms to enter a market. This includes legal barriers, economies of scale, control of resources, and brand loyalty.

questions.question: One of the assumptions underlying the kinked demand curve is that oligopolists
options: Sell to consumers who are less sensitive to price increases than price decreases
Expect their rivals to match any reduction in price
Leave their prices unchanged if a competitor reduces his price
Increase their prices in response to an increase in the price charged by a competitor
questions.explanation: The kinked demand curve model assumes rivals will match price cuts (making demand inelastic below the kink) but not match price increases (making demand elastic above the kink).

questions.question: Refer to the graph 'images/sumo.png'. The graph shows a monopolistically competitive firm:
options: making a profit in the short-run
incurring a loss in the short-run
making a profit in the long-run
questions.explanation: The firm is making a short-run profit because at the profit‑maximizing quantity (where MR = MC), price exceeds average total cost (ATC).

questions.question: What is excess capacity on a graph?
options: gap between profit maximizing output and market demand
difference between actual output and maximum possible output
gap between minimum ATC output and profit maximizing output
distance between current production and ideal efficiency level
questions.explanation: Excess capacity occurs in monopolistic competition because firms produce at a quantity less than the output where ATC is minimized. The gap is between the profit‑maximizing output (MR = MC) and the minimum‑ATC output.

questions.question: What happens to total revenue when marginal revenue hits zero in a monopoly?
questions.explanation: When MR = 0, total revenue is maximized. For a downward‑sloping demand curve, MR becomes negative beyond that point, causing total revenue to fall.

questions.question: What is the socially optimal price?
questions.explanation: The socially optimal price is P = MC, achieving allocative efficiency where total surplus is maximized and deadweight loss is zero.

questions.question: The best strategy for a player to follow regardless of the strategies chosen by the other players
questions.explanation: A dominant strategy yields the best outcome for a player no matter what the opponent does.

questions.question: What are the typical barriers to entry in an oligopoly?
options: low start-up costs, easy access to markets, flexible pricing
economies of scale, high start-up costs, and ownership of raw materials
government subsidies, open market competition, diverse product range
brand loyalty, minimal regulation, standardized production processes
questions.explanation: Oligopolies are characterized by high barriers to entry such as economies of scale, significant capital requirements, control over key resources, and patents.
